newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan stocks soar on heavy foreign buying. [CORRECTED 9:25 GMT 1/6]
newsitem.headline: Jordan stocks soar on heavy foreign buying. [CORRECTED 9:25 GMT 1/6]

text.p: Jordan's stock market soared on Saturday to its highest level since mid-1995 on the heaviest global fund buying spree in years on attractively priced blue chips, dealers said.

Brokers said foreign interest in leading blue chips widened beyond three stocks which have been focus of a two-week old buying spree -- Jordan Cement, Arab Potash and Jordan Phosphate Mines -- to other banks and drug firms.
The official 60-share Amman Financial Market (AFM) index rose 2.42 percent to 162.76 points (Corrects rise in index and closing level) in strong trade worth 6.2 million dinars ($8.8 million).
The bourse has not reached this level since June 12, 1995, its highest level during that year, when it ended the trading session at 162.94 points.
They said price levels for blue chips looked attractive in a market that has fallen around four percent since the start of the year.

Most of the buying orders continued to be executed by two main brokerage firms on behalf of a number of foreign funds lured by the attractively priced stock, while locals were mostly sellers, brokers said.

Jordan Cement shares alone accounted for more than half of Saturday's value of trade, rising 0.02 dinars to close at 4.29 dinars or near a maximum 5 percent daily price ceiling in trade worth nearly 3.4 million dinars.
